member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element could be null sometimes, so the check for null is necessary before its usage.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NotNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element could never be null.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ItemNotNullAttribute
member.summary: Can be appplied to symbols of types derived from IEnumerable as well as to symbols of Task and Lazy classes to indicate that the value of a collection item, of the Task.Result property or of the Lazy.Value property can never be null.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ItemCanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Can be appplied to symbols of types derived from IEnumerable as well as to symbols of Task and Lazy classes to indicate that the value of a collection item, of the Task.Result property or of the Lazy.Value property can be null.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.StringFormatMethodAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method builds string by format pattern and (optional) arguments. Parameter, which contains format string, should be given in constructor. The format string should be in -like form.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Annotations.StringFormatMethodAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Specifies which parameter of an annotated method should be treated as format-string

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ValueProviderAttribute
member.summary: For a parameter that is expected to be one of the limited set of values. Specify fields of which type should be used as values for this parameter.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.InvokerParameterNameAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the function argument should be string literal and match one of the parameters of the caller function. For example, ReSharper annotates the parameter of .

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed.
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output.
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally.
canbenull annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.LocalizationRequiredAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that marked element should be localized or not.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CannotApplyEqualityOperatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked type (or its derivatives) cannot be compared using '==' or '!=' operators and Equals() should be used instead. However, using '==' or '!=' for comparison with null is always permitted.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.BaseTypeRequiredAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a target attribute, specifies a requirement for any type marked with the target attribute to implement or inherit specific type or types.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.UsedImplicitlyAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked symbol is used implicitly (e.g. via reflection, in external library), so this symbol will not be marked as unused (as well as by other usage inspections).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.MeansImplicitUseAttribute
member.summary: Should be used on attributes and causes ReSharper to not mark symbols marked with such attributes as unused (as well as by other usage inspections)

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.Access
member.summary: Only entity marked with attribute considered used.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.Assign
member.summary: Indicates implicit assignment to a member.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.InstantiatedWithFixedConstructorSignature
member.summary: Indicates implicit instantiation of a type with fixed constructor signature. That means any unused constructor parameters won't be reported as such.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseKindFlags.InstantiatedNoFixedConstructorSignature
member.summary: Indicates implicit instantiation of a type.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags
member.summary: Specify what is considered used implicitly when marked with or .

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags.Members
member.summary: Members of entity marked with attribute are considered used.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.ImplicitUseTargetFlags.WithMembers
member.summary: Entity marked with attribute and all its members considered used.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.PublicAPIAttribute
member.summary: This attribute is intended to mark publicly available API which should not be removed and so is treated as used.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.InstantHandleAttribute
member.summary: Tells code analysis engine if the parameter is completely handled when the invoked method is on stack. If the parameter is a delegate, indicates that delegate is executed while the method is executed. If the parameter is an enumerable, indicates that it is enumerated while the method is executed.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.PureAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a method does not make any observable state changes. The same as System.Diagnostics.Contracts.PureAttribute.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.MustUseReturnValueAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the return value of method invocation must be used.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ProvidesContextAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the type member or parameter of some type, that should be used instead of all other ways to get the value that type. This annotation is useful when you have some "context" value evaluated and stored somewhere, meaning that all other ways to get this value must be consolidated with existing one.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.PathReferenceAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a parameter is a path to a file or a folder within a web project. Path can be relative or absolute, starting from web root (~).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.SourceTemplateAttribute
member.summary: An extension method marked with this attribute is processed by ReSharper code completion as a 'Source Template'. When extension method is completed over some expression, it's source code is automatically expanded like a template at call site.
member.remarks: Template method body can contain valid source code and/or special comments starting with '$'. Text inside these comments is added as source code when the template is applied. Template parameters can be used either as additional method parameters or as identifiers wrapped in two '$' signs. Use the attribute to specify macros for parameters.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro for a parameter of a source template.
member.remarks: You can apply the attribute on the whole method or on any of its additional parameters. The macro expression is defined in the property. When applied on a method, the target template parameter is defined in the property. To apply the macro silently for the parameter, set the property value = -1.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Expression
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro that will be executed for a source template parameter when the template is expanded.

members.member:
Allows specifying which occurrence of the target parameter becomes editable when the template is deployed.
If the target parameter is used several times in the template, only one occurrence becomes editable; other occurrences are changed synchronously. To specify the zero-based index of the editable occurrence, use values >= 0. To make the parameter non-editable when the template is expanded, use -1. >

member.name: P:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Target
member.summary: Identifies the target parameter of a source template if the is applied on a template method.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcActionAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC action. If applied to a method, the MVC action name is calculated implicitly from the context. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.ChildActionExtensions.RenderAction(HtmlHelper, String).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcAreaAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Indicates that a parameter is an MVC area. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.ChildActionExtensions.RenderAction(HtmlHelper, String).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcControllerAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC controller. If applied to a method, the MVC controller name is calculated implicitly from the context. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Html.ChildActionExtensions.RenderAction(HtmlHelper, String, String).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcSuppressViewErrorAttribute

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcDisplayTemplateAttribute

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcTemplateAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. Indicates that a parameter is an MVC template. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations.UIHintAttribute(System.String).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcViewAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC view component. If applied to a method, the MVC view name is calculated implicitly from the context. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.Mvc.Controller.View(Object).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcViewComponentAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC view component name.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcViewComponentViewAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. If applied to a parameter, indicates that the parameter is an MVC view component view. If applied to a method, the MVC view component view name is default.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AspMvcActionSelectorAttribute
member.summary: ASP.NET MVC attribute. When applied to a parameter of an attribute, indicates that this parameter is an MVC action name.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.RazorSectionAttribute
member.summary: Razor attribute. Indicates that a parameter or a method is a Razor section. Use this attribute for custom wrappers similar to System.Web.WebPages.WebPageBase.RenderSection(String).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessAttribute
member.summary: Indicates how method, constructor invocation or property access over collection type affects content of the collection.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.None
member.summary: Method does not use or modify content of the collection.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.Read
member.summary: Method only reads content of the collection but does not modify it.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.ModifyExistingContent
member.summary: Method can change content of the collection but does not add new elements.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.CollectionAccessType.UpdatedContent
member.summary: Method can add new elements to the collection.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionMethodAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method is assertion method, i.e. it halts control flow if one of the conditions is satisfied. To set the condition, mark one of the parameters with attribute.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the condition parameter of the assertion method. The method itself should be marked by attribute. The mandatory argument of the attribute is the assertion type.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType
member.summary: Specifies assertion type. If the assertion method argument satisfies the condition, then the execution continues. Otherwise, execution is assumed to be halted.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_TRUE
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to true.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_FALSE
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to false.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_NULL
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to null value.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Annotations.AssertionConditionType.IS_NOT_NULL
member.summary: Marked parameter should be evaluated to not null value.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.TerminatesProgramAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method unconditionally terminates control flow execution. For example, it could unconditionally throw exception.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.LinqTunnelAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that method is pure LINQ method, with postponed enumeration (like Enumerable.Select, .Where). This annotation allows inference of [InstantHandle] annotation for parameters of delegate type by analyzing LINQ method chains.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NoEnumerationAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that IEnumerable, passed as parameter, is not enumerated.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.RegexPatternAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that parameter is regular expression pattern.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.XamlItemsControlAttribute
member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the type that has ItemsSource property and should be treated as ItemsControl-derived type, to enable inner items DataContext type resolve.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.XamlItemBindingOfItemsControlAttribute
member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the property of some BindingBase-derived type, that is used to bind some item of ItemsControl-derived type. This annotation will enable the DataContext type resolve for XAML bindings for such properties.
member.remarks: Property should have the tree ancestor of the ItemsControl type or marked with the attribute.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NoReorder
member.summary: Prevents the Member Reordering feature from tossing members of the marked class.
member.remarks: The attribute must be mentioned in your member reordering patterns

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuConstants.DefaultConsoleCommandLine
member.summary: The default for . Runs the stock ConEmu task for the Windows command line.

summary.para: This is a console emulator control that embeds a fully functional console view in a Windows Forms window. It is capable of running any console application with full interactivity and advanced console functions. Applications will detect it as an actual console and will not fall back to the output redirection mode with reduced interactivity or formatting.

The control can be used to run a console process in the console emulator. The console process is the single command executed in the control, which could be a simple executable (the console emulator is not usable after it exits), or an interactive shell like cmd or powershell or bash, which in turn can execute multiple commands, either by user input or programmatically with . The console emulator is what implements the console and renders the console view in the control. A new console emulator (represented by a ) is started for each console process. After the root console process terminates, the console emulator might remain open (see ) and still present the console window, or get closed. After the console emulator exits, the control is blank until spawns a new console emulator for a console process in it. You cannot run more than one console emulator (or console process) simultaneousely.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuControl._autostartinfo
member.summary: Enabled by default, and with all default values (runs the cmd shell).

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuControl._nLastExitCode
member.summary: After the first console process exits (not session), stores its exit code. Changes on the main thread only.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuControl._running
member.summary: The running session, if currently running.

summary.para: Gets or sets whether this control will start the console process as soon as it's loaded on the form: yes if non-NULL, and no if NULL.
Set this to NULL to prevent the console emulator from opening automatically. Adjust this object or assign a new one to setup the console process to be run in the console emulator automatically.

You can either specify the console executable to run in , or use its default value for the default Windows console and execute your command in that console with (the console will remain operable and ready to run more commands after the command completes).

remarks.para: This object cannot be changed after the first console emulator session starts. The value of the property becomes NULL and cannot be changed either.

If you're chaning NULL to non-NULL and the control has already been loaded, it will start executing a new session with these parameters immediately, so make sure you've completed settings up all the parameters before making the assignment.

member.name: P:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuControl.IsStatusbarVisible
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the status bar of the console emulator view should be visible.

summary.para: Gets the exit code of the most recently terminated console process.
NULL if no console process has exited in this control yet.
Note that if a console process is currently running in the console emulator then you'd be getting the previous exit code until it exits.
Gets the running console emulator session, or NULL if there currently is none.
A session represents an open console emulator view displayed in the control, in which a console process is either still running, or has already terminated.
To guarantee getting the running session object of a short-lived session before it closes, call manually rather than rely on .
This only changes on the main thread.
Gets the current state of the console emulator control regarding whether a console emulator is open in it, and whether there is still a console process running in that emulator.
This only changes on the main thread.
Gets whether a console emulator is currently open, and its console window view is displayed in the control. Of , that's either or .
When a console emulator is not open, the control is blank.
This only changes on the main thread.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuControl.Start(ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuStartInfo)

summary.para: Starts a new console process in the console emulator control, and shows the console emulator view. When a session is not running, the control is blank.
If another session is running, it will be closed, and the new session will replace it. will call and create a session automatically if configured.

remarks.para: The control state transitions to , then to (unless configured to close on exit), then to .

member.returns: Returns the newly-started session, as in .

member.name: E:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuControl.StateChanged
member.summary: Fires on the main thread whenever changes.

summary.para: A single session of the console emulator running a console process. Each console process execution in the control spawns a new console emulator and a new session.

When the console emulator starts, a console view appears in the control. The console process starts running in it immediately. When the console process terminates, the console emulator might or might not be closed, depending on the settings. After the console emulator closes, the control stops viewing the console, and this session ends.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.IsExecutingGuiMacrosInProcess
member.summary: A service option. Whether to load the ConEmu helper DLL in-process to communicate with ConEmu (True, new mode), or start a new helper process to send each command (False, legacy mode).

member.summary: Non-NULL if we've requested ANSI log from ConEmu and are listening to it.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession._dirTempWorkingFolder
member.summary: Per-session temp files, like the startup options for ConEmu and ANSI log cache.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession._guiMacroExecutor
member.summary: Sends commands to the ConEmu instance and gets info from it.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession._lifetime
member.summary: Executed to process disposal.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession._nConsoleProcessExitCode
member.summary: The exit code of the console process, if it has already exited. Null, if the console process is still running within the console emulator.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession._process
member.summary: The ConEmu process, even after it exits.

member.summary: Stores the main thread scheduler, so that all state properties were only changed on this thread.

member.summary: The original parameters for this session; sealed, so they can't change after the session is run.

member.summary: Task-based notification of the console emulator closing.

member.name: F:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession._taskConsoleProcessExit
member.summary: Task-based notification of the console process exiting.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.#ctor(ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuStartInfo,ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.HostContext)
member.summary: Starts the session. Opens the emulator view in the control (HWND given in ) by starting the ConEmu child process and giving it that HWND; ConEmu then starts the child Console Process for the commandline given in and makes it run in the console emulator window.
member.param: User-defined startup parameters for the console process.
Control-related parameters.

summary.para: Gets whether the console process has already exited (see ). The console emulator view might have closed as well, but might have not (see ).
This state only changes on the main thread.
Gets the start info with which this session has been started.
All of the properties in this object are now readonly.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.BeginGuiMacro(System.String)
member.summary: Starts construction of the ConEmu GUI Macro, see http://conemu.github.io/en/GuiMacro.html .

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.Close
member.summary: An alias for .

summary.para: Closes the console emulator window, and kills the console process if it's still running.
This also closes the running session, the control goes blank and ready for running a new session.
To just kill the console process, use . If allows, the console emulator window might stay open after that.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.ExecuteGuiMacroTextAsync(System.String)

summary.para: Executes a ConEmu GUI Macro on the active console, see http://conemu.github.io/en/GuiMacro.html .
This function takes for formatted text of a GUI Macro; to format parameters correctly, better use the and the macro builder.

member.param: The full macro command, see http://conemu.github.io/en/GuiMacro.html .

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.ExecuteGuiMacroTextSync(System.String)

summary.para: Executes a ConEmu GUI Macro on the active console, see http://conemu.github.io/en/GuiMacro.html , synchronously.
This function takes for formatted text of a GUI Macro; to format parameters correctly, better use the and the macro builder.

member.param: The full macro command, see http://conemu.github.io/en/GuiMacro.html .

summary.para: Gets the exit code of the console process, if it has already exited. Throws an exception if it has not.
This state only changes on the main thread.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.KillConsoleProcessAsync

summary.para: Kills the console process running in the console emulator window, if it has not exited yet.
This does not necessarily kill the console emulator process which displays the console window, but it might also close if says so.

member.returns: Whether the process were killed (otherwise it has been terminated due to some other reason, e.g. exited on its own or killed by a third party).

summary.para: Sends the Control+Break signal to the console process, which will most likely abort it.
Unlike , this is a soft signal which might be processed by the console process for a graceful shutdown, or ignored altogether.
Sends the Control+C signal to the payload console process, which will most likely abort it.
Unlike , this is a soft signal which might be processed by the console process for a graceful shutdown, or ignored altogether.
Waits until the console emulator closes and the console emulator view gets hidden from the control, or completes immediately if it has already exited.
Note that the console process might have terminated long before this moment without closing the console emulator unless were selected in the startup options.
Waits for the console process running in the console emulator to terminate, or completes immediately if it has already terminated.
If not , the console emulator stays, otherwise it closes also, and the console emulator window is hidden from the control.
Writes text to the console input, as if it's been typed by user on the keyboard.
Whether this will be visible (=echoed) on screen is up to the running console process.
Writes text to the console output, as if the current running console process has written it to stdout.
Use with caution, as this might interfere with console process output in an unpredictable manner.
Fires on the main thread when the console process writes into its output or error streams. Gets a chunk of the raw ANSI stream contents.
For processes which write immediately on startup, this event might fire some chunks before you can start sinking it. To get notified reliably, use .
To enable sinking this event, you must have set to True before starting the console process.
If you're reading the ANSI log with , it's guaranteed that all the events for the log will be fired before , and there will be no events afterwards.
Fires on the main thread when the console emulator closes and the console emulator window is hidden from the control.
Note that the console process might have terminated long before this moment without closing the console emulator unless were selected in the startup options.
For short-lived processes, this event might fire before you can start sinking it. To get notified reliably, use or .
Fires on the main thread when the console process running in the console emulator terminates.
If not , the console emulator stays, otherwise it closes also, and the console emulator window is hidden from the control.
For short-lived processes, this event might fire before you can start sinking it. To get notified reliably, use or .
If you're reading the ANSI log with , it's guaranteed that all the events for the log will be fired before , and there will be no events afterwards.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuSession.Init_ConsoleProcessMonitoring
member.summary: Watches for the status of the payload console process to fetch its exitcode when done and notify user of that.

summary.para: Creates a new object with all the parameters in their default values.
The console emulator will run the default CMD shell with such an empty object.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.ConEmuStartInfo.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new object and defines the command line for the console process to be run in the console emulator, .
member.param: Value for .

summary.para: Gets or sets an event sink for the event even before the console process starts, which guarantees that your event sink won't miss the early data written by the console process on its very startup.
Settings this to a non-NULL value also implies on .
The base XML configuration for the ConEmu console emulator, in the standard ConEmu settings files XML format.

The initial value of the property returns the configuration file which is used by default in the console emulator control. You can change this very document instance, and it will not affect other sessions.

The final XML settings file which will be supplied to the ConEmu console emulator takes this document as a baseline and applies other relevant properties from this object (as well as host configuration options from the control) on top of it. These changes are applied to a copy, this original document remains unchanged and can be reused.
This property cannot be changed when the process is running.
Advanced configuration.
Gets or sets the path to the ConEmu console extender (ConEmuC.exe).
Normally, will be autodetected from the path to this DLL or from .
Advanced configuration.
Gets or sets the path to the ConEmu console server (ConEmuCD.dll). MUST match the processor architecture of the current process.
Normally, will be autodetected from the path to this DLL or from .
Advanced configuration.
Gets or sets the path to the ConEmu.exe which will be the console emulator root process.
Normally, will be autodetected from the path to this DLL.
Gets or sets an event sink for even before the console process starts, which guarantees that your event sink won't miss events even for short-lived processes.
Alternatively, use for reliable notification.
The command line to execute in the console emulator as the top-level console process. Each console emulator session can run only one console command.
The default is , which opens an interactive CMD shell in the console emulator.
This property cannot be changed when the process is running.
Gets or sets an event sink for even before the console process starts, which guarantees that your event sink won't miss events even for short-lived processes.
Alternatively, use for reliable notification.
Gets or sets the custom greeting text which will be echoed into the console emulator stdout before the starts executing.
Note that to echo the itself you can use the more specific option (which prints after the custom greeting text).
Newline handling: a newline is added automatically at the end, if missing; if there's a single newline at the end, it is retained AS IS. If you want an empty line after text, add a double newline.
The default is an empty string for no custom greeting.
This property cannot be changed when the process is running.
Gets or sets whether the console command line will be echoed into the console emulator stdout before being executed. If there's also , it goes first.
The default is False.
This property cannot be changed when the process is running.
Gets or sets whether the console process is to be run elevated (an elevation prompt will be shown as needed).
The default is False.
This property cannot be changed when the process is running.
Gets or sets whether the ConEmu will write some diagnostics into LogFiles.
LogFiles are created in ConEmu program folder if it's write-enabled, otherwise they would be placed in Desktop folder ConEmuLogs.
The default is Disabled.
This property cannot be changed when the process is running.
Gets or sets whether the console emulator will be reading the raw ANSI stream of the console and firing the events (and notifying ).
This can only be decided on before the console process starts.
Setting to a non-NULL value implies on a True value for this property.

summary.para: Gets or sets whether the console emulator view should remain open and keep displaying the last console contents after the console process specified in terminates.

This property cannot be changed when the process is running.

summary.para: There has been no console emulator opened in this control yet.
The control is now empty, and is NULL. A new session can be started with .
The console emulator is open, and the console process is running in it.
is available. A new session cannot be started until the current session is closed ().
The console emulator is still open, but the console process in it has already exited, even though the console view is still visible in the control.
The console emulator stays open in this case if allows it.
is available. A new session cannot be started until the current session is closed ().
There were a console emulator in this control, but its console process has exited, and then the terminal were closed.
The control is now empty and not showing the console view, and is NULL. A new session can be started with .

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.Util.WinApi.EnumChildWindows(System.Void*,System.Void*,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The EnumChildWindows function enumerates the child windows that belong to the specified parent window by passing the handle to each child window, in turn, to an application-defined callback function. EnumChildWindows continues until the last child window is enumerated or the callback function returns FALSE.
member.param: [in] Handle to the parent window whose child windows are to be enumerated. If this parameter is NULL, this function is equivalent to EnumWindows. Windows 95/98/Me: hWndParent cannot be NULL.
[in] Pointer to an application-defined callback function. For more information, see EnumChildProc.
[in] Specifies an application-defined value to be passed to the callback function.
member.remarks: If a child window has created child windows of its own, EnumChildWindows enumerates those windows as well. A child window that is moved or repositioned in the Z order during the enumeration process will be properly enumerated. The function does not enumerate a child window that is destroyed before being enumerated or that is created during the enumeration process.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.Util.WinApi.MoveWindow(System.Void*,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: The MoveWindow function changes the position and dimensions of the specified window. For a top-level window, the position and dimensions are relative to the upper-left corner of the screen. For a child window, they are relative to the upper-left corner of the parent window's client area.
member.param: [in] Handle to the window.
[in] Specifies the new position of the left side of the window.
[in] Specifies the new position of the top of the window.
[in] Specifies the new width of the window.
[in] Specifies the new height of the window.

[in] Specifies whether the window is to be repainted. If this parameter is TRUE, the window receives a message. If the parameter is FALSE, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of moving a child window.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.Util.WinApi.OpenProcess(System.UInt32,System.Int32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Opens an existing local process object.
member.param: The access to the process object.
If this value is TRUE, processes created by this process will inherit the handle.

The identifier of the local process to be opened. If the specified process is the System Process (0x00000000), the function fails and the last error code is ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER. If the specified process is the Idle process or one of the CSRSS processes, this function fails and the last error code is ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED because their access restrictions prevent user-level code from opening them.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is an open handle to the specified process. If the function fails, the return value is NULL. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:ConEmu.WinForms.Util.WinApi.SetFocus(System.Void*)
member.summary: The SetFocus function sets the keyboard focus to the specified window. The window must be attached to the calling thread's message queue. The SetFocus function sends a WM_KILLFOCUS message to the window that loses the keyboard focus and a WM_SETFOCUS message to the window that receives the keyboard focus. It also activates either the window that receives the focus or the parent of the window that receives the focus. If a window is active but does not have the focus, any key pressed will produce the WM_SYSCHAR, WM_SYSKEYDOWN, or WM_SYSKEYUP message. If the VK_MENU key is also pressed, the lParam parameter of the message will have bit 30 set. Otherwise, the messages produced do not have this bit set. By using the AttachThreadInput function, a thread can attach its input processing to another thread. This allows a thread to call SetFocus to set the keyboard focus to a window attached to another thread's message queue.
member.param: [in] Handle to the window that will receive the keyboard input. If this parameter is NULL, keystrokes are ignored.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the handle to the window that previously had the keyboard focus. If the hWnd parameter is invalid or the window is not attached to the calling thread's message queue, the return value is NULL. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: T:ConEmu.WinForms.Util.WinApi.EnumWindowsProc
member.summary: The EnumWindowsProc function is an application-defined callback function used with the EnumWindows or EnumDesktopWindows function. It receives top-level window handles. The WNDENUMPROC type defines a pointer to this callback function. EnumWindowsProc is a placeholder for the application-defined function name.
member.param: [in] Handle to a top-level window.
[in] Specifies the application-defined value given in EnumWindows or EnumDesktopWindows.
member.returns: To continue enumeration, the callback function must return TRUE; to stop enumeration, it must return FALSE.
member.remarks: An application must register this callback function by passing its address to EnumWindows or EnumDesktopWindows.

member.name: T:ConEmu.WinForms.WhenConsoleProcessExits
member.summary: Controls behavior of the console emulator when the console process running in it terminates.

summary.para: When the console process exits, the console emulator is closed, and its window is hidden from the control.
The control shows blank space, output text disappears.
and are both fired at this moment.
The console emulator control is ready for running a new session.
When the console process exits, the console emulator stays open, and its window remains visible in the control, with all the console output text.
No additional message is written to the console output, but you can still use to write any text.
Pressing ESC or ENTER closes the console emulator, makes the control blank, and allows to run further console emulator sessions in this control.
fires immediately, and fires on user's ESC/ENTER, or when the console emulator is closed programmatically.
When the console process exits, the console emulator stays open, and its window remains visible in the control, with all the console output text.
The message Press Enter or Esc to close console... is displayed.
Pressing ESC or ENTER closes the console emulator, makes the control blank, and allows to run further console emulator sessions in this control.
fires immediately, and fires on user's ESC/ENTER, or when the console emulator is closed programmatically.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder
member.summary: (1) Make sure values containing hyphens are quoted (RC at least requires this) (2) Escape any embedded quotes. -- Literal double quotes should be written in the form \" not "" -- Backslashes falling just before doublequotes must be doubled. -- Literal double quotes can only occur in pairs (you cannot pass a single literal double quote) -- Functional double quotes (for example to handle spaces) are best put around both name and value in switches like /Dname=value.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.summary: Default constructor

member.summary: Returns the length of the current command

member.name: P:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.CommandLine
member.summary: Retrieves the private StringBuilder instance for inheriting classes

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.ToString
member.summary: Return the command-line as a string.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder._quoteHyphens
member.summary: Should hyphens be quoted or not

member.name: F:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder._allowedUnquoted
member.summary: Instead of defining which characters must be quoted, define which characters we know its safe to not quote. This way leads to more false-positives (which still work, but don't look as nice coming out of the logger), but is less likely to leave a security hole.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder._definitelyNeedQuotes
member.summary: Also, define the characters that we know for certain need quotes. This is partly to document which characters we know can cause trouble and partly as a sanity check against a bug creeping in.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.DefinitelyNeedQuotes
member.summary: Use a private property so that we can lazy initialize the regex

member.name: P:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AllowedUnquoted
member.summary: Use a private getter property to we can lazy initialize the regex

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.IsQuotingRequired(System.String)
member.summary: Checks the given switch parameter to see if it must/can be quoted.
member.param: the string to examine for characters that require quoting
member.returns: true, if parameter should be quoted

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendSpaceIfNotEmpty
member.summary: Add a space to the specified string if and only if it's not empty.
member.remarks: This is a pretty obscure method and so it's only available to inherited classes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendTextWithQuoting(System.String)
member.summary: Appends a string. Quotes are added if they are needed. This method does not append a space to the command line before executing.
member.remarks: Escapes any double quotes in the string.
member.param: The string to append

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendQuotedTextToBuffer(System.Text.StringBuilder,System.String)
member.summary: Appends given text to the buffer after first quoting the text if necessary.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendTextUnquoted(System.String)
member.summary: Appends a string. No quotes are added. This method does not append a space to the command line before executing.
member.remarks: In the future, this function may fixup 'textToAppend' to handle literal embedded quotes.
member.param: The string to append

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendFileNameWithQuoting(System.String)
member.summary: Appends a file name. Quotes are added if they are needed. If the first character of the file name is a dash, ".\" is prepended to avoid confusing the file name with a switch This method does not append a space to the command line before executing.
member.remarks: In the future, this function may fixup 'text' to handle literal embedded quotes.
member.param: The file name to append

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendFileNameIfNotNull(System.String)
member.summary: Appends a file name quoting it if necessary. This method appends a space to the command line (if it's not currently empty) before the file name.
member.param: File name to append, if it's null this method has no effect

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendFileNamesIfNotNull(System.String[],System.String)
member.summary: Appends array of file name strings, quoting them if necessary, delimited by a delimiter. This method appends a space to the command line (if it's not currently empty) before the file names.
member.param: File names to append, if it's null this method has no effect
The delimiter between file names

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendSwitch(System.String)
member.summary: Appends a command-line switch that has no separate value, without any quoting. This method appends a space to the command line (if it's not currently empty) before the switch.
member.param: The switch to append to the command line, may not be null

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendSwitchIfNotNull(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Appends a command-line switch that takes a single string parameter, quoting the parameter if necessary. This method appends a space to the command line (if it's not currently empty) before the switch.
member.param: The switch to append to the command line, may not be null
Switch parameter to append, quoted if necessary. If null, this method has no effect.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.VerifyThrowNoEmbeddedDoubleQuotes(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Throws if the parameter has a double-quote in it. This is used to prevent parameter injection. It's virtual so that tools can override this method if they want to have quotes escaped in filenames
member.param: Switch name for error message
Switch parameter to scan

member.name: M:Microsoft.Build.Utilities.CommandLineBuilder.AppendSwitchIfNotNull(System.String,System.String[],System.String)
member.summary: Appends a command-line switch that takes a string[] parameter, and add double-quotes around the individual filenames if necessary. This method appends a space to the command line (if it's not currently empty) before the switch.
member.param: The switch to append to the command line, may not be null
Switch parameters to append, quoted if necessary. If null, this method has no effect.
Delimiter to put between individual parameters, may not be null (may be empty)

member.summary: Appends the literal parameter without trying to quote. This method appends a space to the command line (if it's not currently empty) before the switch.
member.param: The switch to append to the command line, may not be null
Switch parameter to append, not quoted. If null, this method has no effect.

member.param: The switch to append to the command line, may not be null
Switch parameters to append, not quoted. If null, this method has no effect.
Delimiter to put between individual parameters, may not be null (may be empty)
